Count([c:children], assigned_to(c) == assigned_to(Rachel)) == 1 ::: Rachel cannot share a locker

context: During a single week, from Monday through Friday, tours will be conducted of a company's three divisions—Operations, Production, and Sales. question: If in the week's tour schedule the division that is toured on Tuesday is also toured on Wednesday, then which one of the following must be true of the week's tour schedule?

subjects = EnumSort([needlework, origami, pottery, stenciling, textile_making, woodworking])
positions = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
pos = Function([subjects] -> [positions])
teacher_of = Function([subjects] -> [teachers])

# Constraints
teacher_of(needlework) == Jiang ::: Jiang will present on needlework
teacher_of(origami) == Jiang ::: Jiang will present on origami
teacher_of(pottery) == Kudrow ::: Kudrow will present on pottery
teacher_of(stenciling) == Kudrow ::: Kudrow will present on stenciling
teacher_of(textile_making) == Kudrow ::: Kudrow will present on textile making
teacher_of(woodworking) == Lanning ::: Lanning will present on woodworking
Distinct([s:subjects], pos(s)) ::: six consecutive presentations on six different subjects
ForAll([s1:subjects, s2:subjects], Implies(And(pos(s1) + 1 == pos(s2), teacher_of(s1) == Kudrow), teacher_of(s2) != Kudrow)) ::: Kudrow cannot give two presentations in a row
pos(stenciling) < pos(origami) ::: The presentation on stenciling must be given earlier than the one on origami
pos(textile_making) < pos(woodworking) ::: The presentation on textile making must be given earlier than the one on woodworking

is_sat(And(pos(stenciling) == 1, pos(origami) == 2, pos(needlework) == 3, pos(textile_making) == 4, pos(pottery) == 5, pos(woodworking) == 6)) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(pos(stenciling) == 1, pos(origami) == 2, pos(pottery) == 3, pos(woodworking) == 4, pos(needlework) == 5, pos(textile_making) == 6)) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(pos(stenciling) == 1, pos(origami) == 2, pos(textile_making) == 3, pos(woodworking) == 4, pos(needlework) == 5, pos(pottery) == 6)) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(pos(textile_making) == 1, pos(origami) == 2, pos(stenciling) == 3, pos(woodworking) == 4, pos(needlework) == 5, pos(pottery) == 6)) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(pos(textile_making) == 1, pos(stenciling) == 2, pos(woodworking) == 3, pos(needlework) == 4, pos(pottery) == 5, pos(origami) == 6)) ::: (E)

Or(selected(F), selected(G)) ::: At least one dessert must be selected
Or(selected(N), selected(O), selected(P)) ::: At least one main course must be selected

selected(P) == selected(W) ::: If either P or W is selected, both must be selected

Implies(selected(N), Not(selected(V))) ::: If N is selected, V cannot be selected

Distinct([p:professors], position(p)) ::: Each professor gives exactly one guest lecture
ForAll([p:professors], And(1 <= position(p), position(p) <= 7)) ::: The lectures are ordered from first through seventh

Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered. Gladstone must be the third school to which snacks are delivered. The first school to which juices are delivered must be the fourth one to which snacks are delivered.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the condition that Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered, would have the same effect in determining the delivery schedule?
options: A) Ferndale must be either the second school or the fourth school to which juices are delivered.
B) Gladstone must be either the second school or the third school to which juices are delivered.
C) Hafford must be either the first school or the fourth school to which juices are delivered.
D) The first school to which juices are delivered must be either Ferndale or Isley.
E) The fourth school to which juices are delivered must be either Hafford or Isley.

schools = EnumSort([Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford, Isley])
juice_order = Function([schools] -> [IntSort()])
snack_order = Function([schools] -> [IntSort()])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:schools], And(1 <= juice_order(s), juice_order(s) <= 4)) ::: Each school has a juice delivery position from 1 to 4
Distinct([s:schools], juice_order(s)) ::: Each school has a unique juice delivery position
ForAll([s:schools], And(1 <= snack_order(s), snack_order(s) <= 4)) ::: Each school has a snack delivery position from 1 to 4
Distinct([s:schools], snack_order(s)) ::: Each school has a unique snack delivery position
snack_order(Ferndale) < snack_order(Hafford) ::: Snacks must be delivered to Ferndale at some time before they are delivered to Hafford
snack_order(Gladstone) == 3 ::: Gladstone must be the third school to which snacks are delivered
ForAll([s:schools], And(Implies(juice_order(s) == 1, snack_order(s) == 4), Implies(snack_order(s) == 4, juice_order(s) == 1))) ::: The first school to which juices are delivered must be the fourth one to which snacks are delivered

Count([f:flowers], And(contains(bouquet2, f), contains(bouquet3, f))) == 2 ::: Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common

ForAll([b:bouquets], Implies(contains(b, lilies), And(contains(b, roses), Not(contains(b, snapdragons))))) ::: If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons

context: A florist is filling a customer's order for three bouquets—bouquet 1, bouquet 2, and bouquet 3. Each of the bouquets is to be composed of one or more of five kinds of flowers—lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, and tulips—subject to the following conditions: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons. If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons. If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Lilies and roses are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.
B) Peonies and tulips are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.
C) Lilies, peonies, and roses are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 2.
D) Peonies, roses, and snapdragons are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 2.
E) Peonies, snapdragons, and tulips are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 3.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
bouquets = EnumSort([bouquet1, bouquet2, bouquet3])
flowers = EnumSort([lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips])
contains = Function([bouquets, flowers] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:bouquets], Count([f:flowers], contains(b, f)) >= 1) ::: Each of the bouquets is to be composed of one or more of five kinds of flowers
ForAll([f:flowers], Not(And(contains(bouquet1, f), contains(bouquet3, f)))) ::: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common
Count([f:flowers], And(contains(bouquet2, f), contains(bouquet3, f))) == 2 ::: Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common
contains(bouquet3, snapdragons) ::: Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons
ForAll([b:bouquets], Implies(contains(b, lilies), And(contains(b, roses), Not(contains(b, snapdragons))))) ::: If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons
ForAll([b:bouquets], Implies(contains(b, tulips), contains(b, peonies))) ::: If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
is_exception(is_sat(And(contains(bouquet1, lilies), contains(bouquet1, roses), Not(contains(bouquet1, peonies)), Not(contains(bouquet1, snapdragons)), Not(contains(bouquet1, tulips))))) ::: (A)
is_exception(is_sat(And(contains(bouquet1, peonies), contains(bouquet1, tulips), Not(contains(bouquet1, lilies)), Not(contains(bouquet1, roses)), Not(contains(bouquet1, snapdragons))))) ::: (B)
is_exception(is_sat(And(contains(bouquet2, lilies), contains(bouquet2, peonies), contains(bouquet2, roses), Not(contains(bouquet2, snapdragons)), Not(contains(bouquet2, tulips))))) ::: (C)
is_exception(is_sat(And(contains(bouquet2, peonies), contains(bouquet2, roses), contains(bouquet2, snapdragons), Not(contains(bouquet2, lilies)), Not(contains(bouquet2, tulips))))) ::: (D)
is_exception(is_sat(And(contains(bouquet3, peonies), contains(bouquet3, snapdragons), contains(bouquet3, tulips), Not(contains(bouquet3, lilies)), Not(contains(bouquet3, roses))))) ::: (E)

question: Which one of the following is an allowable distribution of bonuses to the seven employees?

D) [Finance] Kimura: $3,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $3,000; Peterson: $1,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $3,000; Xavier: $5,000; Zane: $3,000

dept = Function([employees] -> [departments])
is_he = Function([employees] -> [bool])

# Constraints

dept(Lopez) == Finance ::: Lopez works in the Finance department
dept(Meng) == Finance ::: Meng works in the Finance department
dept(Peterson) == Finance ::: Peterson works in the Finance department
dept(Vaughan) == Graphics ::: Vaughan works in the Graphics department
dept(Xavier) == Graphics ::: Xavier works in the Graphics department
dept(Zane) == Graphics ::: Zane works in the Graphics department
is_he(Lopez) == True ::: Lopez was rated Highly Effective
is_he(Meng) == True ::: Meng was rated Highly Effective
is_he(Xavier) == True ::: Xavier was rated Highly Effective
is_he(Kimura) == False ::: Kimura was not rated Highly Effective

is_sat(And(bonus(Kimura) == 1000, bonus(Lopez) == 5000, bonus(Meng) == 5000, bonus(Peterson) == 3000, bonus(Vaughan) == 3000, bonus(Xavier) == 5000, bonus(Zane) == 1000)) ::: (B)

B) Hill is on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn.
C) Kitson is on desk duty earlier in the week than Moore.
D) Moore is on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung.
E) Moore is on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
librarians = EnumSort([Flynn, Gomez, Hill, Kitson, Leung, Moore, Zahn])
day_of = Function([librarians] -> [IntSort()])

# Constraints
ForAll([l:librarians], And(1 <= day_of(l), day_of(l) <= 6)) ::: Each librarian is scheduled for a day Monday(1) through Saturday(6)
ForAll([d:IntSort()], Implies(And(1 <= d, d <= 5), Count([l:librarians], day_of(l) == d) == 1)) ::: On each day except Saturday, there will be exactly one librarian on duty
Count([l:librarians], day_of(l) == 6) == 2 ::: with two on duty on Saturday
day_of(Hill) < day_of(Leung) ::: Hill must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung
day_of(Hill) < day_of(Gomez) ::: Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez
day_of(Moore) < day_of(Gomez) ::: Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez
day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Kitson) ::: Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore
day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Moore) ::: Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore
day_of(Kitson) < day_of(Zahn) ::: Kitson must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn
Implies(day_of(Leung) != 6, day_of(Leung) < day_of(Flynn)) ::: Unless Leung is on desk duty on Saturday, Leung must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Flynn

# Options
Question ::: If Flynn is on desk duty earlier in the week than Hill, which one of the following must be true?
is_valid(Implies(day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Hill), day_of(Hill) < day_of(Kitson))) ::: (A)
is_valid(Implies(day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Hill), day_of(Hill) < day_of(Zahn))) ::: (B)
is_valid(Implies(day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Hill), day_of(Kitson) < day_of(Moore))) ::: (C)
is_valid(Implies(day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Hill), day_of(Moore) < day_of(Leung))) ::: (D)
is_valid(Implies(day_of(Flynn) < day_of(Hill), day_of(Moore) < day_of(Zahn))) ::: (E)

context: Seven librarians—Flynn, Gomez, Hill, Kitson, Leung, Moore, and Zahn—are being scheduled for desk duty for one week—Monday through Saturday. The librarians will be on duty exactly one day each. On each day except Saturday, there will be exactly one librarian on duty, with two on duty on Saturday, subject to the following constraints: Hill must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung. Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez. Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore. Kitson must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn. Unless Leung is on desk duty on Saturday, Leung must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Flynn.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore, would have the same effect in determining the schedule for the librarians?
options: A) Flynn cannot be on desk duty on Thursday.
B) Only Flynn or Hill can be on desk duty on Monday.
C) Only Hill and Leung can be on desk duty earlier than Flynn.
D) Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Gomez and Kitson.
E) Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Moore and Zahn.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
librarians = EnumSort([Flynn, Gomez, Hill, Kitson, Leung, Moore, Zahn])
days = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
on_duty = Function([librarians] -> [days])

# Constraints
ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)) ::: On each day except Saturday, there will be exactly one librarian on duty
Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2 ::: with two on duty on Saturday
on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung) ::: Hill must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung
on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez) ::: Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez
on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez) ::: Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez
on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson) ::: Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore
on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore) ::: Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore
on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn) ::: Kitson must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn
Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn)) ::: Unless Leung is on desk duty on Saturday, Leung must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Flynn

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore, would have the same effect in determining the schedule for the librarians?
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)), Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2, on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung), on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn), Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn))), And(Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)), on_duty(Flynn) != 4), Implies(on_duty(Flynn) != 4, And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)))))) ::: (A)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)), Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2, on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung), on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn), Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn))), And(Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)), ForAll([l:librarians], Implies(on_duty(l) == 1, Or(l == Flynn, l == Hill)))), Implies(ForAll([l:librarians], Implies(on_duty(l) == 1, Or(l == Flynn, l == Hill))), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)))))) ::: (B)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)), Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2, on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung), on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn), Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn))), And(Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)), ForAll([l:librarians], Implies(on_duty(l) < on_duty(Flynn), Or(l == Hill, l == Leung)))), Implies(ForAll([l:librarians], Implies(on_duty(l) < on_duty(Flynn), Or(l == Hill, l == Leung))), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)))))) ::: (C)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)), Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2, on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung), on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn), Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn))), And(Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson))), Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson)), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)))))) ::: (D)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([d:days], Implies(d <= 5, Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == d) == 1)), Count([l:librarians], on_duty(l) == 6) == 2, on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Leung), on_duty(Hill) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Moore) < on_duty(Gomez), on_duty(Kitson) < on_duty(Zahn), Implies(on_duty(Leung) != 6, on_duty(Leung) < on_duty(Flynn))), And(Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Zahn))), Implies(And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Zahn)), And(on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Kitson), on_duty(Flynn) < on_duty(Moore)))))) ::: (E)

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) slot 1: a finance feature; slot 2: an industry feature; slot 3: a second industry feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a graphic
B) slot 1: a graphic; slot 2: a technology feature; slot 3: a second technology feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a third technology feature
C) slots 1 and 2: a single industry feature; slots 3 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 5: a finance feature
D) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 3: a single industry feature; slot 4: a finance feature; slot 5: a graphic
E) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 3: an industry feature; slot 5: a graphic
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
slots = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
contents = EnumSort([finance, industry, marketing, technology, graphic])
slot_content = Function([slots] -> [contents])
is_feature_start = Function([slots] -> [bool])

# Constraints
is_feature_start(1) == (slot_content(1) != graphic) ::: A feature starts at slot 1 if it is not a graphic
is_feature_start(2) == (And(slot_content(2) != graphic, slot_content(1) != slot_content(2))) ::: A feature starts at slot 2 if it is not a graphic and is different from the content of slot 1
is_feature_start(3) == (And(slot_content(3) != graphic, slot_content(2) != slot_content(3))) ::: A feature starts at slot 3 if it is not a graphic and is different from the content of slot 2
is_feature_start(4) == (And(slot_content(4) != graphic, slot_content(3) != slot_content(4))) ::: A feature starts at slot 4 if it is not a graphic and is different from the content of slot 3
is_feature_start(5) == (And(slot_content(5) != graphic, slot_content(4) != slot_content(5))) ::: A feature starts at slot 5 if it is not a graphic and is different from the content of slot 4
Count([s:slots], is_feature_start(s)) >= 3 ::: There are at least three features per issue
And(Implies(And(slot_content(1) != graphic, slot_content(2) != graphic), slot_content(1) == slot_content(2)), Implies(And(slot_content(2) != graphic, slot_content(3) != graphic), slot_content(2) == slot_content(3)), Implies(And(slot_content(3) != graphic, slot_content(4) != graphic), slot_content(3) == slot_content(4)), Implies(And(slot_content(4) != graphic, slot_content(5) != graphic), slot_content(4) == slot_content(5))) ::: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots
Implies(Exists([s:slots], Or(slot_content(s) == finance, slot_content(s) == technology)), Or(slot_content(1) == finance, slot_content(1) == technology)) ::: If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1
Count([s:slots], And(is_feature_start(s), slot_content(s) == industry)) <= 1 ::: An issue can have at most one industry feature

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
is_sat(And(slot_content(1) == finance, slot_content(2) == industry, slot_content(3) == industry, slot_content(4) == graphic, slot_content(5) == graphic)) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(slot_content(1) == graphic, slot_content(2) == technology, slot_content(3) == technology, slot_content(4) == graphic, slot_content(5) == technology)) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(slot_content(1) == industry, slot_content(2) == industry, slot_content(3) == marketing, slot_content(4) == marketing, slot_content(5) == finance)) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(slot_content(1) == technology, slot_content(2) == industry, slot_content(3) == industry, slot_content(4) == finance, slot_content(5) == graphic)) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(slot_content(1) == technology, slot_content(2) == marketing, slot_content(3) == industry, slot_content(4) == marketing, slot_content(5) == graphic)) ::: (E)

question: If an issue of the newsletter has no technology feature and if there is a finance feature that occupies both slots 4 and 5, then which one of the following is required for that issue?
options: A) A finance feature occupies slot 1.
B) A finance feature occupies slot 2 or slot 3 or both.
C) A marketing feature occupies slot 2.
D) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 2.
E) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 3.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
slots = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
features = EnumSort([finance, industry, marketing, technology, graphic])
contains = Function([slots] -> [features])

# Constraints
Count([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == graphic)) >= 3 ::: at least three features per issue
ForAll([s1:slots, s2:slots, s3:slots], Implies(And(s1 < s2, s2 < s3, contains(s1) == contains(s3), Not(contains(s1) == graphic)), contains(s2) == contains(s1))) ::: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots
Implies(Or(Exists([s:slots], contains(s) == finance), Exists([s:slots], contains(s) == technology)), Or(contains(1) == finance, contains(1) == technology)) ::: If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1
Count([s:slots], contains(s) == industry) <= 1 ::: An issue can have at most one industry feature

# Options
Question ::: If an issue of the newsletter has no technology feature and if there is a finance feature that occupies both slots 4 and 5, then which one of the following is required for that issue?
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == technology)), And(contains(4) == finance, contains(5) == finance)), contains(1) == finance)) ::: (A)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == technology)), And(contains(4) == finance, contains(5) == finance)), Or(contains(2) == finance, contains(3) == finance))) ::: (B)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == technology)), And(contains(4) == finance, contains(5) == finance)), contains(2) == marketing)) ::: (C)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == technology)), And(contains(4) == finance, contains(5) == finance)), Or(contains(2) == industry, contains(2) == marketing))) ::: (D)
is_valid(Implies(And(ForAll([s:slots], Not(contains(s) == technology)), And(contains(4) == finance, contains(5) == finance)), Or(contains(3) == industry, contains(3) == marketing))) ::: (E)

Each employee has ranked the offices from first (highest) to fourth (lowest) as follows: Jackson: Y, X, Z, W Larabee: X, Z, W, Y Paulson: Y, Z, X, W Torillo: X, Y, Z, W The following restrictions must apply: Each employee selects an office that has not been selected previously. Each employee selects only one office. Each employee selects the office that he or she ranks highest among the unselected offices.
question: Which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Jackson does not select office X.
B) Larabee does not select office W.
C) Larabee does not select office Z.
D) Torillo does not select office X.
E) Paulson does not select office X.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
employees = EnumSort([Jackson, Larabee, Paulson, Torillo])
offices = EnumSort([W, X, Y, Z])
order = IntSort()
selects = Function([employees] -> [offices])
selects_at = Function([order] -> [employees])
rank = Function([employees, offices] -> [IntSort()])

# Constraints
Distinct([e:employees], selects(e)) ::: Each employee selects a different office
ForAll([o:order], And(1 <= o, o <= 4)) ::: Order is 1, 2, 3, 4
Distinct([o:order], selects_at(o)) ::: The selection order is a permutation of the employees
And(rank(Jackson, Y) == 1, rank(Jackson, X) == 2, rank(Jackson, Z) == 3, rank(Jackson, W) == 4, rank(Larabee, X) == 1, rank(Larabee, Z) == 2, rank(Larabee, W) == 3, rank(Larabee, Y) == 4, rank(Paulson, Y) == 1, rank(Paulson, Z) == 2, rank(Paulson, X) == 3, rank(Paulson, W) == 4, rank(Torillo, X) == 1, rank(Torillo, Y) == 2, rank(Torillo, Z) == 3, rank(Torillo, W) == 4) ::: Employee rankings
ForAll([o:order], ForAll([f_prime:offices], Implies(Not(Exists([o_prime:order], And(o_prime < o, selects(selects_at(o_prime)) == f_prime))), rank(selects_at(o), selects(selects_at(o))) <= rank(selects_at(o), f_prime)))) ::: Each employee selects the office that he or she ranks highest among the unselected offices

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following must be true?
is_valid(selects(Jackson) != X) ::: (A)
is_valid(selects(Larabee) != W) ::: (B)
is_valid(selects(Larabee) != Z) ::: (C)
is_valid(selects(Torillo) != X) ::: (D)
is_valid(selects(Paulson) != X) ::: (E)

context: Exactly five volunteers—Haddad, Joslin, Kwon, Molina, and Nash—are being assigned to three community committees—X, Y, and Z. Each committee will have three volunteers assigned to it, with each volunteer on a committee holding exactly one of three positions—leader, secretary, or treasurer. The following conditions apply: If Nash is assigned to a committee, Nash must be the leader for that committee. Molina must be assigned to exactly one committee. Kwon must be assigned to Y but cannot be assigned to Z. Joslin must be the secretary for Y but cannot be assigned to X or Z.
question: Which one of the following could be the assignment of volunteers to Z?
options: A) leader: Haddad; secretary: Molina; treasurer: Joslin
B) leader: Joslin; secretary: Haddad; treasurer: Molina
C) leader: Kwon; secretary: Haddad; treasurer: Molina
D) leader: Molina; secretary: Nash; treasurer: Haddad
E) leader: Nash; secretary: Molina; treasurer: Haddad
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
volunteers = EnumSort([Haddad, Joslin, Kwon, Molina, Nash])
committees = EnumSort([X, Y, Z])
positions = EnumSort([leader, secretary, treasurer])
assigns = Function([volunteers, committees, positions] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([c:committees, p:positions], Count([v:volunteers], assigns(v, c, p)) == 1) ::: Each committee will have three volunteers assigned to it, with each volunteer on a committee holding exactly one of three positions
ForAll([v:volunteers, c:committees], Count([p:positions], assigns(v, c, p)) <= 1) ::: A volunteer holds at most one position on any given committee
ForAll([c:committees], Implies(Count([p:positions], assigns(Nash, c, p)) > 0, assigns(Nash, c, leader))) ::: If Nash is assigned to a committee, Nash must be the leader for that committee
Count([c:committees], Count([p:positions], assigns(Molina, c, p)) > 0) == 1 ::: Molina must be assigned to exactly one committee
Count([p:positions], assigns(Kwon, Y, p)) > 0 ::: Kwon must be assigned to Y
ForAll([p:positions], Not(assigns(Kwon, Z, p))) ::: Kwon cannot be assigned to Z
assigns(Joslin, Y, secretary) ::: Joslin must be the secretary for Y
ForAll([p:positions], Not(assigns(Joslin, X, p))) ::: Joslin cannot be assigned to X
ForAll([p:positions], Not(assigns(Joslin, Z, p))) ::: Joslin cannot be assigned to Z

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the assignment of volunteers to Z?
is_sat(And(assigns(Haddad, Z, leader), assigns(Molina, Z, secretary), assigns(Joslin, Z, treasurer))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(assigns(Joslin, Z, leader), assigns(Haddad, Z, secretary), assigns(Molina, Z, treasurer))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(assigns(Kwon, Z, leader), assigns(Haddad, Z, secretary), assigns(Molina, Z, treasurer))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(assigns(Molina, Z, leader), assigns(Nash, Z, secretary), assigns(Haddad, Z, treasurer))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(assigns(Nash, Z, leader), assigns(Molina, Z, secretary), assigns(Haddad, Z, treasurer))) ::: (E)

context: In one week—Monday through Friday—a library's bookmobile will visit five of the following six neighborhoods—Hidden Hills, Lakeville, Nottingham, Oldtown, Park Plaza, and Sunnyside. Exactly one neighborhood will be visited on each of the five days, and none of the neighborhoods will be visited on more than one day. The bookmobile's schedule must conform to the following conditions: Hidden Hills is visited, but not on Friday. If Oldtown is visited, then it is visited on the day immediately before Hidden Hills is visited. If Lakeville is visited, then it is visited on Wednesday. Nottingham and Sunnyside are both visited, but not on consecutive days.
question: The five neighborhoods visited by the bookmobile, listed in order from Monday through Friday, could be
options: A) Nottingham, Lakeville, Oldtown, Hidden Hills, and Sunnyside
B) Nottingham, Oldtown, Hidden Hills, Sunnyside, and Park Plaza
C) Oldtown, Hidden Hills, Lakeville, Nottingham, and Sunnyside
D) Sunnyside, Oldtown, Lakeville, Hidden Hills, and Nottingham
E) Sunnyside, Park Plaza, Nottingham, Oldtown, and Hidden Hills

days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
neighborhoods = EnumSort([Hidden_Hills, Lakeville, Nottingham, Oldtown, Park_Plaza, Sunnyside])
visits = Function([days] -> [neighborhoods])

# Constraints
Distinct([d:days], visits(d)) ::: Exactly one neighborhood will be visited on each of the five days, and none of the neighborhoods will be visited on more than one day

computers = EnumSort([P, Q, R, S, T, U])

# Constraints
Exists([c:computers], And(is_source(c), ForAll([c2:computers], Implies(c2 != c, Not(is_source(c2)))))) ::: Exactly one computer was infected from outside the network

ForAll([c:computers], Implies(Not(is_source(c)), Count([p:computers], transmits_to(p, c)) == 1)) ::: Each computer received the virus exactly once
ForAll([c:computers], Count([r:computers], transmits_to(c, r)) <= 2) ::: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers

Exists([p:computers], And(transmits_to(p, R), transmits_to(p, S))) ::: The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S
Or(transmits_to(R, Q), transmits_to(T, Q)) ::: Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q
Or(transmits_to(T, P), transmits_to(U, P)) ::: Either T or U transmitted the virus to P
